central_thesis: This section of the Talmud Eser Sefirot meticulously details the intricate process of emanation and restriction within the divine realms, particularly focusing on the structure and interactions of the Partzufim (Divine Personae) of Adam Kadmon (AK) and the subsequent emergence and 'breaking' of the vessels of Olam ha Nekudim (World of Points). It emphasizes the crucial role of conscious restriction (Tzimtzum), the formation of spiritual barriers (Parsa), and the complex mechanisms of cause and effect (Zivugim, MAN) that lead to the 'death of the kings' (Shevirat ha Kelim), thereby laying the foundational esoteric blueprint for the necessity of cosmic rectification (Tikun) and humanity's operative role within it.

structure_content.chapter_title: 1. AK contains AB SAG MA BON in its Atzmut.
structure_content.summary: This point introduces the internal structure of Adam Kadmon (AK), specifying its four primary Komot (levels): AB, SAG, MA, and BON. It elaborates that each Koma contains all four levels within itself, and that the Orot (Lights) emanating from them are called Anafim (branches). The focus is placed on Partzuf SAG, whose Koma reaches Bina, and its correspondence to various levels within Atzilut, particularly AB and Abba de Atzilut in its Mochin, and its SAG corresponding to Bina de Atzilut from Awzen down to Tabur. The MA and BON of SAG correspond to ZON de Atzilut from its Tabur down. The initial expansion of SAG reaching Sium Raglaim of inner AK is mentioned, followed by its ascent to the Tabur after the Tzimtzum of NHY.

structure_content.chapter_title: 2. As in its Pnimiut, so in the Orot that stem from it, which are its branches.
structure_content.summary: This section details the division and emanation of the Se'arot (hairs or branches) of Rosh (Head) and Dikna (Beard) of Partzuf SAG. The Se'arot Rosh are described as being opposite the branches of AB and relate to the Keter and Hochma of SAG's Rosh (Galgalta and Eynaim). The Se'arot Dikna originate from the AHP (Awzen, Hotem, Peh) of SAG, corresponding to the branches of SAG itself, and are considered the Behinat Guf. AVI (Abba, Ima, Israel Saba) are contained within these Se'arot and play a role in their structure and correction after Tzimtzum NHY, rising to Eynaim and forming Komat ZA. This process is paralleled with AVI de Atzilut's emergence from Dikna de AA, and the Eser Sefirot de Nekudim's emergence from Dikna de Rosh SAG.

structure_content.chapter_title: 3. In the beginning, AK was thus: its first three are AB – Keter, SAG - Hochma and Bina.
structure_content.summary: This point reiterates the initial state of AK, with its first three Partzufim (AB-Keter, SAG-Hochma, Bina). It explains that SAG, through its lower half (Nekudot), clothed MA and BON de AK from the Tabur down, constituting the Pnimiut (interiority) of AK (Atzmut, Orot, Kelim). SAG itself contains Hochma and Bina, despite its overall Koma (level) being Bina. The two Zivugim (matings) within SAG, for Komat Hochma (Zachar) and Komat Bina (Nekeva), are described. The distinction between Taamim (Ohr Yashar, Rachamim) and Nekudot (Ohr Hozer, Din) within SAG's Sefirot is clarified, with Taamim associated with Keter de Guf and Nekudot with the lower nine Sefirot. The lower nine Sefirot of SAG, having Komat Ohr Bina, expanded below Tabur de AK, filling the ZON.

structure_content.chapter_title: 4. After that it generated the exterior Behinot to clothe it.
structure_content.summary: This section explains the generation of exterior Behinot (aspects) that clothe the interior Partzufim. First, Orot (Lights) from the general, interior AB formed the Se'arot of the Keter, encompassing SAG's Rosh from Metzach to Awznaim. Subsequently, the Se'arot of the Zakan were generated from the general SAG (called Nekudim), from which the collective three Mochin (KHB) of Nekudim were formed. The Se'arot are divided into Rosh (up to Awznaim, considered AB) and Guf (from Awznaim down, considered SAG/Nekudim), with the latter being the AHP that emerged from the Rosh.

structure_content.chapter_title: 5. First the Taamim de SAG extended, which is AHP through its Tabur.
structure_content.summary: This point describes the initial extension of Taamim de SAG, which represents the AHP (Awzen, Hotem, Peh) extending through its Tabur. These Taamim are identified as Ohr Yashar and Rachamim, primarily consisting of the Zachar (masculine) aspect with Komat Hochma. It's noted that these Taamim did not bring forth other Behinot because they were clothed inside MA and BON, functioning as the Orot of the collective AB. The lower nine Sefirot of SAG, though not initially brought forth, later expanded to fill the ZON below Tabur de AK, thus being referred to as MA and BON.

structure_content.chapter_title: 6. Then it wanted to bring the Hitzoniut of the inner MA and BON in it outwardly.
structure_content.summary: This section details the ascent of all inner Behinot SAG, including the inner MA and BON (which are Reshimot of lower nine Sefirot de SAG mingled with Aviut de Behina Dalet), as MAN (Mayin Nukvin). This ascent to Malchut de Rosh for a new Zivug (mating) serves to renew and expand the Partzuf. The mingled Reshimot (Orot de SAG, Aviut de Behina Bet, and Orot of inner MA/BON, Aviut de Behina Dalet) form a combined MAN, which then incorporates into the Upper Zivug. This process ultimately leads to the procreation of exterior BON and the 'birth' of the Nekeva (feminine aspect), emphasizing that the changes are additional forms rather than cancellations of previous states like 'Matei ve Lo Matei'.

structure_content.chapter_title: 7. When the Maatzil wanted to emanate Olam ha Nekudim, His intention was to make them Kelim so as to have strength in the lower Olamot to receive the Ohr Elyon.
structure_content.summary: This point explains the necessity of a second Tzimtzum (restriction), referred to as Tzimtzum Bet, in AK, prior to the emanation of Olam ha Nekudim. The purpose was to enable the lower Olamot (worlds) to receive the Ohr Elyon (Higher Light). The Maatzil (Emanator) observed that the Tachtonim (lower ones) lacked the strength to receive the Orot (Lights) emanating from Nikvey Eynaim (Eye-holes) and expanding from Tabur de AK. Consequently, all Ohr that expanded in the Pnimiut (interiority) of AK from its Tabur downward ascended above the Tabur into its Upper half of the Guf, leaving the lower place without Ohr. This new Tzimtzum, caused by the mixture of Reshimot de SAG and Behina Dalet, moved the Sium (end) to Behina Bet, establishing the Tabur de Olam ha Nekudim, which became the boundary for the Olamot BYA.

structure_content.chapter_title: 8. The learned one shall understand and will conclude one thing from another, how in all the Olamot, the Ne'etzalim that shine in the Olam below them are always Behinat lower half de Tifferet and NHY.
structure_content.summary: This point establishes a general principle concerning the structure of emanated beings across all worlds: the lower world's emanations always manifest as the lower half of Tifferet and the NHY (Netzach, Hod, Yesod) of their preceding, higher world. This hierarchical relationship is illustrated by examples like NHY de AA shining for ZA, and NHY de Atik Yomin for AA. It also reinforces the idea that Tzimtzum is essential for every elicitation of Orot.

structure_content.chapter_title: 9. Thus, after He restricted Himself, He placed one Parsa in the middle of its Guf, inside its place of Tabur, to separate between the two.
structure_content.summary: This section describes the placement of the Parsa (firmament/barrier) in the Guf (Body) of AK, specifically at the Tabur, to create a separation. This Parsa is explained as the 'ending of the Masach' (screen) of the Partzuf, analogous to the toes of the Raglaim. Its formation occurred after the Zivug (mating) in Nikvey Eynaim, which caused the Zivug place to ascend from Peh (Mouth) to Eynaim (Eyes) of the Rosh (Head). This resulted in the Eser Sefirot of the Rosh being divided into Rosh and Guf, and similarly dividing the Eser Sefirot de Sium of Partzuf SAG. The Parsa's function is to restrict the Ohr, dividing the 'waters from the waters', and it 'draws from above and gives below', a concept to be explained further.

structure_content.chapter_title: 10. Certainly, through the Histalkut Ohr above Tabur, it was sufficient for Olam Atzilut to be able to receive their Ohr.
structure_content.summary: This point explains that the initial Histalkut (withdrawal) of Ohr above Tabur was sufficient for Olam Atzilut to receive its diminished Ohr. However, it was insufficient to give strength to Olam Beria (Creation) to receive its Ohr. Therefore, an additional Behina (aspect) was added – the Parsa – to establish a new Masach (screen) and barrier. This implies that the 'new Ohr' emerging through this ascent was diminished, making it receivable for Atzilut, but a further mechanism (Parsa) was needed for Beria to receive light.

structure_content.chapter_title: 11. We should provide the reason why these two things were needed: first, the Tzimtzum; second, the laying down of the Parsa.
structure_content.summary: This section clarifies the dual necessity of the Tzimtzum (restriction) and the Parsa. The Tzimtzum was needed to diminish the Ohr (Light) so that the Kelim (Vessels) of Nekudim, which are inherently restrictive, could tolerate and receive it. This diminution caused the Ohr to be squeezed tightly, leading to its intense emergence through the Eynaim (Eyes) and expansion below. The Parsa, in addition to the Tzimtzum, was necessary to further diminish the Orot specifically for Olam Beria below Atzilut, enabling Beria to receive its elicited Ohr, establishing the Masach and Parsa between Atzilut and Beria.

structure_content.chapter_title: 12. It was also necessary to place the Parsa and diminish the Orot that come out through the Parsa.
structure_content.summary: This point further elaborates on the Parsa's function, stating it's not only for Olam ha Nekudim (Atzilut) but primarily for Olam Beria. The Parsa, described as a 'double Masach' of Behina Bet and Behina Dalet, needs to 'fissure' (annul its Gevul) to allow Orot de SAG to pass below it to Beria. This fissuring is likened to an 'opening that closes and opens', dependent on the descent of Behina Dalet. The Parsa corrected here for Partzuf SAG de AK sets the Gevul (boundary) of Olam ha Nekudim at its Tabur. The concept of 'remoteness of location' is distinguished from an 'actual Masach', where Parsa adds a specific Tikun (rectification) for Orot Atzilut to pass into Beria.

structure_content.chapter_title: 13. The learned one shall thus understand what is written, that any emergence of renewed Orot and additional Olamot is only by Tzimtzum Ohr.
structure_content.summary: This point emphasizes that all renewed Orot (Lights) and subsequent Olamot (Worlds) emerge solely through Tzimtzum Ohr (Restriction of Light), aligning with the initial Tzimtzum Ein Sof for AK and AK for Nekudim (Atzilut). This process is intimately linked to the 'abolition of the Melachim' (kings), as new emanations are prohibited from the Peh (Mouth) due to its high spiritual place. The core of Kli (vessel) formation is seen in the Tzimtzum and Histalkut (withdrawal) of Ohr, which marks the Sium (end) and cessation of Atzilut de SAG and acts as a boundary between Atzilut and BYA.

structure_content.chapter_title: 14. After the above-mentioned Tzimtzum and Parsa, it is found that there are many Orot there in the place of the Chazeh, and their ascent for Mayin Nukvin was beneficial there.
structure_content.summary: Following the Tzimtzum and Parsa, an abundance of Orot (Lights) appeared in the Chazeh (Chest) of SAG. Their ascent for Mayin Nukvin (MAN) was beneficial, causing the division of AVI (Abba, Ima, Israel Saba, Tvuna) into two parts each. This process involved the ascent of NHY de AK (Behina Dalet and Bet) to form MAN in Taamim de SAG, rising to Nikvey Eynaim. This created a division in the Eser Sefirot de Rosh SAG into GE (Rosh) and AHP (Guf), making YESHSUT (GAR de Nekudim) Komat ZA. The descent of Behina Dalet from the Parsa, driven by Hitpashtut (expansion) of YESHSUT, allowed the Inner AB to mate with Rosh de SAG, restoring the lower Hey to the Peh and making the Zivug in Peh de Rosh create a new Koma up to Keter.

structure_content.chapter_title: 15. Then these Orot from its Tabur down that rose in the place of the Chazeh were there as Mayin Nukvin to the Nukva, which are Taamim de SAG, and through these MAN was the aforementioned Zivug.
structure_content.summary: This point explains that the Orot (Lights) that ascended from Tabur down to the Chazeh functioned as Mayin Nukvin (MAN) for the Taamim de SAG, which represents the Nukva (feminine aspect). This MAN enabled a Zivug (mating) that procreated a 'new Ohr'. This new Ohr then descended and 'fissured' the Parsa. The fissuring is attributed to the presence of numerous Orot above the Parsa (in the Chazeh) which the place lacked the strength to tolerate, forcing the Parsa to open and allow the Ohr to descend, filling the previously empty space below the Tabur. This is likened to the Zohar's concept of 'draws from above, and gives below'.

structure_content.chapter_title: 16. Indeed, the Ohr that was first down and ascended, remained after that forever in the Chazeh and did not come down in the Parsa.
structure_content.summary: This section explains that the first Ohr (Light) that initially descended and then ascended (referring to YESHSUT) permanently remained in the Chazeh (Chest) and did not descend again below the Parsa, establishing its Shoresh (root) there. From this position, it expanded through the Eynaim (Eyes), forming the Nekudim, and extended outwardly to the Sium Raglin of AK. In contrast, the 'new Ohr' that descended through the Parsa fissured the Kelim (Vessels) and Guf (Body) of AK, illuminating the Nekudim via 'holes' (hair, Tabur, Yesod). This new Ohr is said to fissure twice: once through the Parsa and again through the 'walls of the Kelim of AK', specifically for the benefit of Nekudim.

structure_content.chapter_title: 17. However the first Ohr that was down in the beginning and then ascended, did not descend again. It remained there from Tabur up and laid its Shoresh there for good.
structure_content.summary: This point clarifies that the first Ohr, specifically the actual Orot of YESHSUT (the 'first Ohr') which had ascended, did not descend again. It remained permanently from the Tabur upward, establishing its spiritual root there. Although the lower Hey (Behina Dalet) descended and the Partzufim reunified, the Parsa itself remained strong, acting as a permanent boundary for YESHSUT, which thus remained above the Tabur. Only its He'arah (illumination) reached down to complete the GAR de Nekudim. The text refers to the entire Ohr extending through Tabur as being 'swallowed and incorporated in Akudim', yet the Ohr below Tabur to Raglaim is called Nekudot, standing alone.

structure_content.chapter_title: 18. Also, that Ohr that comes down through the Parsa a second time, by this above Zivug fissures the Guf and the Kli de Adam Kadmon as well, then exits and shines in these Nekudim.
structure_content.summary: This section distinguishes the two types of Ohr (Light) for Nekudim. The Ohr that comes down through the Parsa a second time is the 'new Ohr' procreated by the Zivug (mating) of MAN (Mayin Nukvin) from the previous section. This Ohr is powerful enough to fissure (break) the Guf (Body) and Kli (Vessel) of Adam Kadmon itself. Once fissured, it exits and illuminates the Nekudim. This implies a deeper penetration and a more transformative action than previous emanations, directly addressing the conditions of the Nekudim.

structure_content.chapter_title: 19. There is yet another, necessary, third Ohr. When the Ohr Ayin comes down through the Akudim, it looks at these Orot AHP; it sucks from there and takes the Ohr to make the Kelim of the Nekudot from them.
structure_content.summary: This point introduces a third, necessary Ohr: the Ohr Ayin (Light of the Eye), which descends through the Akudim. This Ohr's function is to 'look' at and 'suck' from the Orot (Lights) of the AHP (Awzen, Hotem, Peh) to form the Kelim (Vessels) of the Nekudot. These AHP Orot, which became Behinat Guf (vessels of reception) when the Rosh divided, are specifically identified as the Se'arot Dikna (Beard Hairs). The Ohr Ayin extracts from Orot Awzen Hotem Peh to make the Kelim, emphasizing that these vessels transform from Behinat Rosh to Behinat Guf, becoming receivers for the Ohr Eynaim.

structure_content.chapter_title: 20. The thing is that in this manner it's been explained that the Orot of the Awzen expanded to Shibolet ha Zakan, and Orot Hotem Peh pass through there as well.
structure_content.summary: This section explains how the Ohr Eynaim (Light of the Eye) from AK extends through the Awzen, Hotem, and Peh (AHP), mingling with their Orot and taking them to form the Kelim of Nekudim. The 'first three' Nekudot receive Ohr from the Histaklut Ayin (gaze of the eye) in AHP, specifically from Shibolet ha Zakan upward, being considered Israel Saba ve Tvuna, which is incorporated in Akudim. The 'seven lower' Nekudot take only from the Histaklut (gaze) of Orot of Hotem and Peh from Shibolet ha Zakan downward, corresponding to the real Guf of Partzuf Nekudim. The distinction between these two groups is based on their origin and the nature of their reception of Ohr Eynaim.

structure_content.chapter_title: 21. We therefore find that three points take He'arah for their Kelim from the three Orot AHP, specifically in the Shibolet.
structure_content.summary: This point highlights that the first three points (KHB of Nekudim) receive their He'arah (illumination) from the three Orot (Awzen, Hotem, Peh) of the AHP, specifically at the Shibolet ha Zakan. However, the Ohr of the Upper Awzen is blocked at Shibolet ha Zakan, meaning it does not shine below this point, while the ZAT (lower seven) only receive from Hotem and Peh. This results in the He'arah for the three upper points being greater than that for the seven lower ones. The Shibolet ha Zakan is linked to the Parsa, both formed by Tzimtzum NHY and the ascent of the lower Hey, acting as a boundary for Ohr Awzen. Thus, the three points correspond to the three Kelim of Bina, ZA, Malchut that define the ending points of Ohr Bina (Shibolet), Ohr ZA (Chazeh), and Ohr Malchut (Tabur).

structure_content.chapter_title: 22. For this reason, the first three Melachim did not die, since they have a great He'arah and their Kli is very fine, as it is made of Behinat Upper Awzen, the Hotem and the Peh.
structure_content.summary: This section explains why the first three Melachim (kings) – Keter, Hochma, Bina – did not 'die' (break their vessels) unlike the lower seven. They possessed a 'great He'arah' (illumination) and their Kelim (vessels) were very fine, deriving from Upper Awzen, Hotem, and Peh, specifically from Ohr Awzen (Ohr Bina). In contrast, the seven lower Melachim died because they lacked this Ohr GAR (Great Light) from the beginning of their creation, and thus could not tolerate the He'arah from Yesod de AK. This distinction emphasizes the critical role of the source and quality of light in sustaining the vessels.

structure_content.chapter_title: 23. Thus, even in GAR themselves there is a division between this and that. It is so because not even the Achoraim descended from Keter, but only the Achoraim of NHY. However, in AVI of Nekudim, their Achoraim descended alone, and their Panim remained in their place.
structure_content.summary: This point details the internal division within GAR (Keter, Hochma, Bina) and its Achoraim (back) and Panim (face) aspects. It explains how Keter drew from Awzen, Abba (Hochma) from Hotem, and Ima (Bina) from Peh, forming their respective Kelim (vessels) for Nekudim. Keter de Nekudim is identified as Zachar (masculine) with Komat Behina Bet, receiving Etzem Ohr Awzen. Abba de Nekudim is Nekeva (feminine) with Behina Aleph, receiving Ohr Hotem and Peh. The distinction lies in Keter receiving the essence (Atzmut) of Ohr Awzen, while Abba and Ima receive only its He'arah (illumination), impacting the endurance of their Achoraim.

structure_content.chapter_title: 24. The Kli of Keter, which took its great He'arah from the Awzen, did not break. However, AVI, which take only from the Hotem and the Peh, the Achoraim of their Kelim broke.
structure_content.summary: This section explains why Keter's Kli (vessel) did not break, while AVI's (Abba ve Ima) Kelim did. Keter, identified as Zachar, received the actual Ohr Awzen (Ohr Bina) and thus retained its Atzmut (essence), enabling its Achoraim (back part) to remain intact. Conversely, AVI, being Nekeva (feminine) and initially possessing only Behina Aleph, only received a general He'arah (illumination) from Hotem and Peh (Ohr ZA), not the essence. Despite their Hitkalelut (incorporation) with Zachar in the first Zivug (mating), this He'arah was insufficient, leading to the breaking of their Achoraim and the fall of their Panim.

structure_content.chapter_title: 25. These Nekudim expanded from Tabur de AK to its Sium Raglaim, as in the arrangement of ZON, clothing AA. However, there ZON clothes AA all around its sides and surroundings, whereas here, their primary He'arah is only through Panim de AK.
structure_content.summary: This point describes the expansion of the Nekudim from Tabur de AK to its Sium Raglaim (end of legs), akin to how ZON clothes AA. However, a key distinction is made: while ZON clothes AA 'all around its sides and surroundings,' the Nekudim primarily receive their He'arah (illumination) through Panim (face) de AK. Although some He'arah also expands through the sides (right and left, representing Hassadim), the Panim remains the primary channel. The concept of Panim (face) denotes the receptivity of Hochma and GAR (Great Lights), while Achor (back) signifies incapacity to receive them.

structure_content.chapter_title: 26. The place of Keter from the Nekudot is from Tabur de AK through the Sium of the Guf. HBD are in the first three Prakin de NHY de AK, HGT in the three middle Prakin, and NHY in the three lower Prakin, as in ZON that clothes over AA.
structure_content.summary: This section outlines the spatial arrangement and internal divisions of the Nekudim. Keter de Nekudim is located from Tabur de AK to the Sium of the Guf. The text introduces the concept of Sefirat Daat and explains that the Guf of Nekudim begins from Daat, encompassing only the lower seven Sefirot (Daat, HGT, NHY). The GAR de Nekudim (Israel Saba ve Tvuna) is identified with AHP, which became Guf due to the ascent of the lower Hey. The division of NHY de AK into three Prakin (divisions) corresponds to Bina, ZA, and Malchut of Nekudim, forming Netzah, Hod, Yesod as Rosh, Toch, and Sof respectively. This reflects the transformation of higher Sefirot into lower ones (e.g., Hesed becoming Hochma) during Gadlut (expansion).

structure_content.chapter_title: 27. Two kinds of Ohr come out of the Guf de AK: the first from the Tabur, and the second from the Yesod. Also, two Havalim come out through there.
structure_content.summary: This section discusses the emanation of two types of Ohr (Light) and two Havalim (vapors/influences) from the Guf (Body) de AK: one from the Tabur and another from the Yesod. It specifically states that the Haval (vapor) opposite the Awzen is absent from AVI (Abba ve Ima), as they primarily draw from Hotem and Peh. Consequently, only two Havalim (from Peh of Yesod) emerge, corresponding to Hotem and Peh, which AVI received. The absence of the Awzen Haval means ZAT (lower seven) do not receive from the Ohr Awzen, as it ends at Shibolet ha Zakan.

structure_content.chapter_title: 28. However, the Ohr of the lower seven that took only from the Guf down is from the Sium of Shibolet ha Zakan downward.
structure_content.summary: This point explains that the Ohr (Light) received by the lower seven Nekudim (Melachim) originates from the Sium (end) of Shibolet ha Zakan downward. This implies they lack the Havalim associated with the Upper Awzen, but are sustained by a different form of influence, metaphorically referred to as 'the arms of his hands were made supple,' signifying the 'ten additions thrown off from the Tzipornaim' (nails), mentioned in Tikun 69. These Melachim are inherently Dinim (judgments), and their initial annulment (breaking) was due to their uncorrected state as 'one Adam, male and female'.

structure_content.chapter_title: 29. The fitting Havalim for these seven Melachim came out through the Tzipornaim of the Raglaim. Although the Tzipornaim are ten, and the Nekudot that broke are only ZAT, the thing is that there are also two kinds of Achoraim de Ima that broke, being the nine Behinot, and the tenth.
structure_content.summary: This point describes that the Havalim (vapors/influences) for the seven Melachim (kings) emerged through the Tzipornaim (nails) of the Raglaim (feet). While the Tzipornaim are ten, and only the ZAT (lower seven Nekudot) broke, it is explained that ten Behinot (aspects) broke in total. This includes two kinds of Achoraim (back part) de Ima (the nine Behinot), and the tenth is the NHY (Netzach, Hod, Yesod) of Keter, which also broke because they were incorporated as Mochin (brains) into AVI. This emphasizes the widespread impact of the breaking of vessels, extending beyond the initially perceived seven lower Sefirot.

structure_content.chapter_title: 30. Regarding the Akudim, the Behinat Taamim Nekudot, Tagin, Otiot in them has already been explained above. Here we shall explain them in the Behinat Nekudim.
structure_content.summary: This section revisits the concepts of Taamim, Nekudot, Tagin, and Otiot, first defined within Akudim, and now reinterprets them within the context of Nekudim. In Nekudim, the 'first Orot' (Nekudot) emerged first in a state of Katnut (smallness), followed by Gadlut (expansion) when AB and SAG mated. This contrasts with previous Partzufim where Taamim emerged first. The Otiot are identified as the Kelim (vessels) containing Nitzotzin (sparks) from the Histalkut (withdrawal) of Orot. Taamim is now given the 'new name' MA, emerging later from Ohr Metzach for the Tikun (rectification) of the Melachim.

structure_content.chapter_title: 31. We shall repeat that we have explained that the Nekudot were divided into three parts: The Elyonim above the Otiot, such as the Holam, in the middle, like the Shuruk, and the Tachtonim like the rest of the Nekudot.
structure_content.summary: This point details the division of Nekudot into three parts, corresponding to the vowel points: Holam (Elyonim - upper) above the Otiot (Kelim), Shuruk (Middle) in the Vav, and the rest (Tachtonim - lower) as other Nekudot. Holam represents Keter de Nekudim (Ohr Bina, Behina Bet), which exits from Tabur, has no Kelim, and does not clothe within the Otiot. Shuruk represents AVI (Abba and Ima), which are Nekeva, have Kelim, and are implied in the Vav of Shuruk within the Otiot. The Yod of Shuruk is for Abba (five Hassadim), and the Vav is for Ima (VAK de ZA). The seven lower Nekudot are the ZAT, receiving Havalim from Tzipornaim. This highlights the intricate connection between vowel points and the Sefirotic structure of Nekudim, and their relationship to the Orot (Lights) and Kelim.

structure_content.chapter_title: 32. In the beginning of my studies with my teacher, he would hide, cover and clothe the matters, as I did not yet know the beginning of things, as I have presented them in the previous gates.
structure_content.summary: This point introduces a personal reflection from the author, Baal HaSulam, concerning his learning process. He notes that his teacher initially 'hid, covered, and clothed' these profound matters, as he was not yet ready for their full disclosure. This suggests a pedagogical approach where complex esoteric concepts are revealed progressively. The author expresses a desire to present this particular teaching about Atik Yomin despite its apparent contradiction with previously explained concepts, acknowledging the advanced and nuanced nature of the information being conveyed. This signals a deeper, more specialized level of instruction, moving beyond initial understandings.

structure_content.chapter_title: 33. It turns out that the Partzufim AA, AVI and ZON after the Tikun, came out of these Behinot in the seven lower Nekudot, both from the Behinat Orot, and from the Behinat Kelim.
structure_content.summary: This section explains that the rectified Partzufim of Atzilut – AA, AVI, and ZON – emerged from the Behinot (aspects) in the seven lower Nekudot, drawing from both their Orot (Lights) and Kelim (Vessels). These seven lower Nekudot, though initially from Keter, are considered GAR (Great Lights) from the perspective of their emanation in Katnut (smallness). It is noted that these Partzufim (AA, AVI, ZON) mingled with the first three Nekudot (Atik Yomin), which are entirely Atik Yomin, during their rectification. This implies a sorting and correction process where the 'new MA' selected and rectified elements from the lower Nekudim, forming the foundation for the stable Partzufim of Atzilut.

structure_content.chapter_title: 34. It is known that the Elyon expands in any Tachton to sustain it, but the Tachton does not expand in its Elyon. Hence there is the force of Atik Yomin in the seven lower Nekudot, but no force of AA, AVI and ZON is involved in the first three Nekudot, as they are all Behinat Atik.
structure_content.summary: This point states a fundamental Kabbalistic principle: a higher spiritual entity (Elyon) expands into and sustains a lower one (Tachton), but the Tachton does not expand into the Elyon. Applying this, Atik Yomin's influence is present in the seven lower Nekudot to sustain them. However, the forces of AA, AVI, and ZON are absent from the first three Nekudot because these upper Nekudot are considered entirely Behinat Atik (an aspect of Atik Yomin), implying a purer, more primordial level that does not require sustenance from subsequent Partzufim like AA, AVI, or ZON.

structure_content.chapter_title: 35. However, the Upper Maatzil wanted to create that Behinat Melachim in that manner to begin with, consisting of Behinat Kedusha, but she is Dinim and Gevurot and the Shmarim and the Klipot are mixed in them.
structure_content.summary: This section reveals the deliberate intention of the Upper Maatzil (Emanator) to create the Behinat Melachim (kings) of Olam ha Nekudim with an inherent mixture. Initially, they were created with Kedusha (holiness) but simultaneously contained Dinim (judgments), Gevurot (severities), Shmarim (dregs), and Klipot (shells). This admixture was a conscious act to establish the mechanism of reward and punishment in the world. The ultimate purpose of this deliberate creation and mixture was to enable their eventual abolition and extermination, leading to the sorting out of the holy Nitzotzot (sparks) from the Klipot (impurities), thus serving the higher aim of rectification.

structure_content.chapter_title: 36. Know, that these seven Melachim are ten, but they are like the seven Heichalot, which are ten that are called seven. It is so because the top Heichal contains the first three Heichalot, and the bottom Heichal contains the last two Heichalot.
structure_content.summary: This point addresses a seeming paradox: the 'seven Melachim' (kings) are also described as 'ten', yet they are structured like the 'seven Heichalot' (palaces) which are also 'ten'. This is explained by the principle that the 'top Heichal' (Keter) contains the first three (Keter, Hochma, Bina), and the 'bottom Heichal' (Malchut) contains the last two (Yesod, Malchut). Since these Melachim are primarily Behinot Dinim (judgments) and Gevurot (severities), they are collectively considered in the form of Nekeva (feminine), as the Nekeva embodies Din.

structure_content.chapter_title: 37. He wrote, "Come and see the very beginning of faith etc." "trampled over the black Nitzotz," which is the Shoresh of the Din, "concealed in the intestine of Ima," as mentioned in the Zohar (Idra Zuta), "and threw Nitzotzin in 320 directions."
structure_content.summary: This section quotes the Zohar to describe the origin of the Melachim as 'black Nitzotz' (sparks), representing the Shoresh (root) of Din (judgment). These Dinim, emanating from the 'Butzina de Kardinuta' (Candle of Darkness), were initially 'trampled over' and 'concealed in the intestine of Ima'. They are fierce Gevurot (severities) numbering 320 Nitzotzin, each scattering in a different direction below Olam Atzilut. This scattering facilitated the sorting out of the 'offal' (impurities) from within them, leading to their correction. The good and holy Nitzotzin ascended to be corrected by the eighth Melech (Hadar), while the offal transformed into Klipot (shells) and remained below.

structure_content.chapter_title: 38. Indeed these ten Nekudot were one atop the other. The measure of their Koma was as the current measure and Koma of Atzilut, this is because the place where those Nekudot reached, until that place it is now Olam Atzilut, and from there down, Olam Beria.
structure_content.summary: This point describes the initial state of the ten Nekudot, specifically the GAR (Great Lights) of Nekudim, as being 'one atop the other' in a vertical column, without distinct separation. Their Koma (level) was equivalent to that of Atzilut. This signifies that the area they encompassed, down to their reaching point, defined the boundary of Olam Atzilut, with Olam Beria commencing from that point downward. This unified state is analogous to Akudim, where the Behina Bet de Hitlabshut dominated, and the Yod Kelim (vessels) were indiscernible, implying that the Partzuf's Aviut (thickness) was not apparent from below upward.

structure_content.chapter_title: 39. However, the Ohr of these ten Nekudim was great indeed. Also, the Ohr Elyon was added to them, and they did not have the strength to receive. It is then that these Kelim died, meaning went below, to the place that is now Beria, and this descent was their death.
structure_content.summary: This point describes the 'Shevirat ha Kelim' (Breaking of Vessels) of Olam ha Nekudim. While the initial Ohr (Light) of the ten Nekudim was great, an additional Ohr Elyon (Higher Light) was added. The Kelim (vessels) of the lower seven Nekudot were too small to contain this immense additional light, particularly because they were primarily from Bina downward (Behina Aleph) and lacked the appropriate Masach (screen) for the GAR light. Consequently, these Kelim 'died' – they broke and descended to Olam Beria. The GAR (upper three) had the capacity to receive the Ohr and thus did not break. The 'death' is linked to their simultaneous emanation and breakage from Akudim, described as 'the craftsman crushes the iron and Nitzotzin come out, and quench instantaneously'.

structure_content.chapter_title: 40. In the beginning the ten were simple Atzmut, consisting of Yod, indiscernible in them. The GAR, which were Rachamim, could receive the Ohr Ein Sof, and when it reached the seven Nekudot, they would be canceled.
structure_content.summary: This section details the initial, simple state of the ten Nekudim as 'Atzmut' (essence) and 'Yod' (point-like), without clear discernment of their individual vessels. The GAR (Great Lights) of these Nekudim, being Behinat Rachamim (mercy), possessed the potential to receive the Ohr Ein Sof (Light of the Infinite). However, the lower seven Nekudot, being primarily Behinat Din (judgment), lacked the capacity to receive this Rachamim light and thus were 'canceled' (broke their vessels). This led to a correction where Kelim were made for Keter, allowing the Ohr to pass through a corrected Masach, making the Yod apparent. The lower seven Melachim (kings) are identified as those that 'died' due to this inability to receive.

structure_content.chapter_title: 41. Each of these ten Sefirot certainly consisted of all the ten Sefirot, but that was by way of admixture. [Let us make an allegory such as this: it is as if water and wine, oil, honey and milk were all mixed together in the same pot.]
structure_content.summary: This point explains that each of the ten Sefirot in Olam ha Nekudim, though individually manifested, inherently contained all ten Sefirot within itself through a process of 'admixture.' This mixing is likened to various liquids in a single pot, signifying that different spiritual qualities (like Behina Bet and Behina Dalet) were intertwined, especially due to the Tzimtzum NHY and the correction of the Masach through Hochma and Nikvey Eynaim. The lower seven Sefirot were specifically in Behinat Dinim (judgments) and Klipot (shells) because the world's existence and governance necessitate their presence for reward and punishment.

structure_content.chapter_title: 42. However, the Din was below in the lower seven, but everything was mixed together. Because of that there wasn't any correction in the Yod Sefirot at all.
structure_content.summary: This section explains that in the lower seven Nekudot, the Din (Judgment) was mixed with other qualities, resulting in an absence of correction in their Yod Sefirot. When the Ohr Ein Sof (Infinite Light) descended and fissured, it flowed from Keter to Hochma and then to Bina. However, upon reaching the lower seven, which were steeped in Dinim, the immensely expanding Ohr Elyon (Higher Light), being complete Rachamim (Mercy) and Hesed (Lovingkindness), clashed with these Dinim. As opposites, the Dinim were 'awakened' and could not receive the Ohr, leading to their cancellation and 'death,' as described by the biblical phrase 'And Bela died, And Husham died,' signifying the breaking of vessels.

structure_content.chapter_title: 43. Then these seven lower Melachim descended below in Olam Beria, completely under the place of Malchut de Atzilut.
structure_content.summary: This section describes the fate of the seven lower Melachim (kings) after the breaking of vessels: they descended below Olam Beria, beneath the place of Malchut de Atzilut. This left a vacant space ('under Sefirat Bina') in Atzilut. Into this vacant space, another seven Sefirot emerged, mingling together in the image of Adam, composed of Zachar (masculine) and Nekeva (feminine). These new Sefirot form ZON, specifically identified as the eighth Melech, Hadar, and his wife, Mehetabel. This signifies a replacement and rectification process where new, more stable Partzufim fill the void left by the broken vessels.

structure_content.chapter_title: 44. Thus, when you count the Name from AB, each Behinat AB will be Yod from HaVaYaH, and SAG, the first Hey of HaVaYaH, MA is the Ot Vav, and BON is the last Ot Hey.
structure_content.summary: This point details the correspondences of the Partzufim of AK (AB, SAG, MA, BON) to the letters of the Name HaVaYaH (Yod, Hey, Vav, Hey). It then explains how these correspondences shift when counting only from Partzuf SAG: Taamim de SAG corresponds to Ot Yod, Nekudot to the first Ot Hey, Tagin to Ot Vav, and Otiot to the last Hey. A further division of Taamim de SAG reveals specific letter correspondences for Awzen (Yod), Hotem (first Hey), Peh (Vav), and Eynaim (last Hey), emphasizing that Ayin (eye) itself carries the aspects of both last Hey and first Hey, reflecting different levels of emanation and spiritual attributes within the Name.

structure_content.chapter_title: 45. This is the meaning of what is written in the Tikkunim (Zohar), “І sleep" opposite the last Hey. In the annulment of Ohr Nekudim, “I sleep".
structure_content.summary: This section interprets the phrase 'I sleep' in the Zohar's Tikkunim as referring to the 'last Hey' and the annulment of Ohr Nekudim, signifying the 'sleeping' or withdrawal of light caused by the breaking of vessels. The 'last Hey' is the point where the primary breakage occurred. It further explains the hierarchical relationship of Taamim (Keter), Nekudot (Hochma), Tagin (Bina), and Otiot (lower seven), and identifies Ayin (eye) with Hochma (Nekudot). The 'eyes of the congregation' (Ayin) represent the Nekudot, explaining why 'if it be done in error by the congregation, it being hid from their eyes' is significant, as a fault in perception or action affects the higher spiritual realms.

structure_content.chapter_title: 46. These Nekudot are Behinat Melachim that ruled in Eretz (land of) Edom and died. This is also the meaning of "ve ha Aretz Haita Tohu ve Bohu" (Now the earth was unformed and void).
structure_content.summary: This point explicitly identifies the Nekudot with the Behinat Melachim (kings) who 'ruled in Eretz Edom and died.' Eretz is linked to the 'last Hey' and Ayin, signifying the physical world and the vessel most prone to breakage. The phrase 've ha Aretz Haita Tohu ve Bohu' (the earth was unformed and void) refers to the state of chaos and disarray resulting from the death of these Melachim due to the breaking of their Kelim (vessels). Their 'death' signifies a lack of light and a state of unrectified potential, which awaits 'Tikun' (rectification) to bring forth 'light' and correct the desolation, thus aligning with the Kabbalistic concept of the primordial cosmic catastrophe.

structure_content.chapter_title: 47. In order to understand that verse, we shall explain the matter of the Ayin. It is said that there are nine Nekudot: Kamatz, Patach, Tzere, Segol, Shva, Holam, Shuruk, Hirik, Kubutz.
structure_content.summary: This section delves into the 'Ayin' (eye) by detailing the nine Nekudot (vowel points): Kamatz, Patach, Tzere, Segol, Shva, Holam, Shuruk, Hirik, Kubutz, and their upper, middle, and lower Behinot. These nine Nekudot correspond to three primary Orot (Lights): Holam (Hevel of Tabur, Ohr Holam, Behinat Peh of first Rosh/YESHSUT), Shuruk (Hevel ha Yesod, Ohr Shuruk, Behinat Inner ZON), and the lower Nekudot (Ohr from Peh de Nekudim). Holam shines above the Otiot (Kelim) and does not clothe in them. Shuruk shines inside the Kelim de AVI. The Ohr from Peh de Nekudim signifies the lower Nekudot extending under the Kelim de Elyon, reflecting the various levels of light's interaction with the vessels and their respective degrees of elevation and reception.

structure_content.chapter_title: 48. Now, all the last seven Nekudot are in the form of Yodin (pl. for Yod), except the first two Nekudot, Kamatz Patach. These are two Vavin (pl. for Vav), and Yod.
structure_content.summary: This point explains that the last seven Nekudot are primarily 'Yodin' (plural of Yod, representing small, point-like vessels), with the exception of the first two, Kamatz and Patach. Kamatz and Patach are described as 'Yod and two Vavin,' forming the Gimatria 22, which corresponds to the 22 Otiot (letters) from which the Kelim de Nekudim were made. This distinction emphasizes that Kamatz (Keter) and Patach (Hochma) are the Shoresh (root) of all Nekudot and constitute the GE (Galgalta ve Eynaim) of GAR de Nekudim. The Yodin represent the further diminished vessels of the AHP, which experienced Kimutz (thrift/blockage) and Situm (blockage) due to the connection of the lower Hey in the Eynaim, making their Koma (level) Behina Aleph (ZA) and causing them to be Achor be Achor (back-to-back).

structure_content.chapter_title: 49. It is not surprising that the Kelim were registered and implied in the first two Nekudot, the best among them. The thing is that the Kelim for the rest of the Nekudot were made of these first two Nekudot, namely Keter Hochma.
structure_content.summary: This section explains why the Kelim (vessels) of the lower seven Nekudot were 'registered and implied' within the first two Nekudot (Keter and Hochma), which were the 'best among them' and did not break. The first two (Keter/Hochma) retained their Kelim, preserving the Orot within. This signifies that Keter and Hochma of Nekudim served as the progenitors and elicitors of the Kelim for the Sefirot below them. The 'death' of the seven lower Nekudot is attributed to the breaking of their Kelim, leaving them with only Ohr (Light) and not a functioning vessel, distinguishing them from the enduring first three.

structure_content.chapter_title: 50. The Kamatz indicates the Keter, and the Keter is Taamim. The Patach indicates Hochma, and they are the Nekudot. Hence, these two Nekudot are called Kamatz and Patach, as they imply the above matter.
structure_content.summary: This point explains the symbolic representation of Kamatz and Patach. Kamatz indicates Keter, which is Taamim (essence). Patach indicates Hochma, which is Nekudot (vessels). When the Behinat Nekudot (Hochma-Patach, corresponding to Ayin) emerged, they 'opened in the opening of the eyes,' signifying an activation and revelation of light. In contrast, the Taamim (Keter-Kamatz) remained 'blocked and stint,' meaning their Orot (Lights) were not fully revealed. This distinction highlights the different operational modes of the initial and subsequent emanations in Olam ha Nekudim, with Nekudot opening the channels that Taamim had kept closed.

structure_content.chapter_title: 51. Now we shall return to the matter of the verse "open Thine eyes."
structure_content.summary: This section returns to the meaning of 'open Thine eyes' in relation to the Ayin (eye) and the Nekudot. It clarifies that the entire system discussed, including the annulment of the Melachim (kings), is encompassed within the 'name SAG.' SAG, representing Bina (Upper Gevura), is where the Dinim (judgments) are dependent, making it the locus of the Melachim's annulment. Even within SAG itself, Taamim (AB) and Nekudot (SAG de SAG) are distinguished, with the annulment and 'death' specifically occurring in the Nekudot de SAG. This 'impure' state is symbolized by 'they are together become impure,' and the annulment of the Melachim is implied in 'Nasogu Achor' (they are turned away back), referring to the return of order and the future Tikun Kelim.

structure_content.chapter_title: 52. The Ayin is also named after SAG, like the above AHP. This is because when there were the above three Behinot AHP, which are the Taamim, their name SAG was Behinat HaVaYaH, which is SAG: Yod, Hey, Vav, Hey. However, in the Ayin, which is Behinot Nekudot, it is the SAG of three times Ekie, which is also SAG in Gimatria, and this is the SAG in the Ayin.
structure_content.summary: This section reinforces the connection of Ayin (eye), representing the Nekudot, with SAG. While the three Behinot AHP (Awzen, Hotem, Peh) as Taamim were identified with the Name HaVaYaH of SAG, the Ayin (Nekudot) is specifically identified with the Gimatria (numerical value) of SAG. The Ayin contains the 'SAG of three times Ekie,' implying a deep, internal numerical and structural correspondence. This emphasizes the profound and intricate layers of meaning embedded within the names and numerical values, linking the spiritual 'eye' (Ayin) to the core emanative force of SAG, particularly in the context of the Nekudot.

structure_content.chapter_title: 53. Now, all these Ekie from these three, take all the Behinot twenty-two Otiot, implied in the Kamatz Patach, to make of them Kelim through the Histaklut Ayin in them. Thus, each of their names Ekie consists of all the Behinot twenty-two Otiot.
structure_content.summary: This point explains the formative process of Kelim (vessels) in Nekudim. The three 'Ekie' names, originating from the Ayin (representing Nekudot), integrate all the 'twenty-two Otiot' (letters) that are implied within Kamatz Patach. This integration occurs through the 'Histaklut Ayin' (gaze of the eye), which enables the construction of the vessels. Each 'Ekie' name, therefore, embodies the full set of twenty-two Otiot. The combined Gimatria (numerical value) of the three 'Ekie' names, including the Kolel (the principle of inclusion), amounts to 130, which is the Gimatria of 'Ayin,' demonstrating how the Name SAG is intrinsically implied within the Ayin and its role in forming the vessels.

structure_content.chapter_title: 54. This is the meaning of “open Thine eyes, and behold," because in AHP there are three times SAG, which is Pekach (open) in Gimatria, with the Kolel, and after them comes Behinat Eynaim.
structure_content.summary: This concluding point interprets the phrase 'open Thine eyes, and behold our desolations.' 'Open Thine eyes' (Pekach in Gimatria, with Kolel, equals 161) signifies the activation of the Behinat Eynaim (Light of the Eyes) after the three times SAG in AHP. This opening occurs when the Nekuda attached to Patach descends from the Eynaim, allowing the Eynaim to 'open' and form a Patach, symbolizing a state of greater revelation. The 'behold our desolations' refers to the great spiritual desolation and annulment of the Melachim (kings) caused by the breaking of vessels. This comprehensive breakdown, from the lower Hey descending to the Peh and the YHV ascending, ultimately leads to the rectification of the entire Tikun Kelim, restoring divine order.

key_concepts.definition: Divine Personae or configurations within Adam Kadmon, representing distinct stages and levels of emanation (e.g., Keter, AB, SAG, MA, BON). Each Partzuf is a complete system of ten Sefirot, embodying specific spiritual qualities and functions.

Divine emanations or attributes that serve as channels for the flow of divine light. In the context of Olam ha Nekudim, they are often described as Kelim (vessels) that contain Orot (lights), and their interactions are central to the creation and rectification process.

A primordial stage of emanation where the Sefirot emerged as 'points' or 'vowel points.' This world is characterized by its initial structural instability, leading to the catastrophic 'breaking of vessels' (Shevirat ha Kelim) in its lower seven Sefirot, which forms the basis for subsequent rectification efforts.

The process of divine contraction or self-limitation, crucial for creating a 'vacated space' where emanated worlds can exist. The text distinguishes between the initial Tzimtzum Ein Sof and a 'second Tzimtzum' (Tzimtzum Bet or Tzimtzum NHY) within AK, which further diminished the Ohr and set new boundaries for Olam ha Nekudim and Olam Beria.

A spiritual screen or filter that restricts the direct, overwhelming flow of Ohr Elyon (Higher Light). It determines the level of light that can be received by a Kli (vessel) and plays a key role in the formation of Partzufim and their internal dynamics, including its purification and ascent (Hizdakchut) for drawing down new light.

Orot are the divine emanations or lights, representing consciousness and influence. Kelim are the spiritual vessels or containers that receive and contain the Orot. The interplay between Ohr and Kelim, particularly the capacity of Kelim to contain the intensity of Ohr, is fundamental to the stability and functionality of spiritual worlds, with the 'breaking of vessels' occurring when Kelim are insufficient for the Ohr.

A spiritual upward arousal or petition from lower spiritual entities (Nukvin/feminine aspects) that draws down higher divine lights (Ohr Elyon) for the purpose of rectification (Tikun). It represents the conscious effort and desire from below that evokes a response from above, crucial in the Zivugim (matings) between Partzufim.

A distinct spiritual barrier established after Tzimtzum Bet, located in the Guf (Body) of AK at its Tabur. Its primary function is to separate Olam Atzilut from the lower worlds of Beria, Yezirah, Asiya (BYA), and to further diminish and regulate the flow of Ohr. The 'fissuring' of the Parsa implies a temporary opening to allow light to pass, often requiring specific spiritual dynamics.

A pivotal event in Lurianic Kabbalah where the vessels (Kelim) of the lower seven Sefirot of Olam ha Nekudim could not contain the immense Ohr Elyon (Higher Light) and consequently 'broke.' This resulted in the descent of the broken Kelim to Olam Beria and the scattering of divine sparks (Nitzotzin), creating a state of spiritual disarray that necessitates cosmic rectification (Tikun).

The overarching process of repairing the spiritual damage caused by the Shevirat ha Kelim. It involves sorting and elevating the scattered Nitzotzin, reconstructing the broken vessels, and restoring divine order and harmony across the spiritual worlds, a process in which human spiritual actions play a vital role.

The Sefirot of Olam ha Nekudim, particularly the lower seven, are referred to as 'Melachim' or 'kings' (specifically 'the kings who ruled in Edom and died'). This designation emphasizes their initial ruling capacity and their subsequent 'death' or breakage, which led to the primordial cosmic flaw.

practical_system.description: The practical system embedded within this text is primarily intellectual and contemplative, providing the foundational esoteric 'physics' for understanding and participating in cosmic rectification (Tikun). It is not a grimoire of spells but rather a highly detailed blueprint for aligning one's consciousness with the processes of divine emanation and repair. The core operative mechanism involves comprehending the interplay of Ohr (Light) and Kelim (Vessels), the necessity of Tzimtzum (Restriction), the function of the Masach (Screen), and the spiritual dynamics of Zivugim (matings) that lead to the ascent of MAN (Mayin Nukvin). The 'operative' side is about conscious, intellectual engagement with these dynamics to facilitate the drawing down of higher light and the sorting of sparks from the breaking of vessels.
tools: Detailed knowledge of the Kabbalistic Tree of Life, Partzufim, Sefirot, Tzimtzum, Masach, Parsa, and the dynamics of Ohr and Kelim (functioning as a spiritual map).
Gimatria and letter correspondences (e.g., HaVaYaH, Ekie) as a means to understand and interact with specific spiritual structures and forces.
rituals: Study and contemplation (Hitbonenut) of the complex interactions of Partzufim and Sefirot, viewed as a form of Kavanah (intentional meditation) that influences higher worlds.

The 'raising of MAN' (Mayin Nukvin), a core Kabbalistic practice involving a spiritual petition or arousal from below to draw down divine light, implicitly driven by the practitioner's heightened consciousness and desire for rectification.

relevant_quotes.text: AK contains AB SAG MA BON in its Atzmut. Each of these four consists of all four and Orot stem from it, which are its Anafim. The AB is in its Mochin and corresponds to AA and Abba de Atzilut.
He says that it contains AB SAG MA BON in its Atzmut, which are the four Komot that come out over the above four Behinot.
The Rav speaks of Partzuf SAG de AK here, and the details and matters elucidated before us revolve only around that Partzuf.
Know, that in fact, SAG stretches down to the Sium Raglaim of the inner AK... However, after the Tzimtzum of NHY (to be explained later), it rose and ended at the Tabur.

Then it wanted to bring the Hitzoniut of the inner MA and BON in it outwardly. In that state all the inner Behinot SAG, concealed in the inner MA and BON rose, and the inner MA and BON rose along with them. Thus these MA and BON are their MAN, to the Taamim de SAG themselves, which are not clothed inside MA and BON.

The Masach ascends to Malchut de Rosh to mingle there in the Zivug of the Rosh, to be renewed and expand from there to a new Partzuf... This Masach has now acquired a new name, which is MAN, the initials for Mayin Nukvin (Aramaic – Female Waters).

When the Maatzil wanted to emanate Olam ha Nekudim, His intention was to make them Kelim so as to have strength in the lower Olamot to receive the Ohr Elyon. The MaatzilI, Ein Sof, saw that there is still no strength and ability in the Tachtonim to receive these Orot that exit through the Nikvey Eynaim and expand from the place of Tabur de AK to its Raglaim. Consequently, before He emanated these Orot, there was another, second Tzimtzum in AK...

Thus, after He restricted Himself, He placed one Parsa in the middle of its Guf, inside its place of Tabur, to separate between the two. This is the meaning of the verse, “Let there be a firmament in the midst of the waters, and let it divide the waters from the waters."
The thing is that for the Tachtonim to be able to receive the Ohr, it must be diminished and come through Masachim.

However, the Ohr of these ten Nekudim was great indeed. Also, the Ohr Elyon was added to them, and they did not have the strength to receive. It is then that these Kelim died, meaning went below, to the place that is now Beria, and this descent was their death.
It is impossible for the world to exist and be conducted except through the Dinim and the Klipot.
These Nekudot are Behinat Melachim that ruled in Eretz (land of) Edom and died. This is also the meaning of "ve ha Aretz Haita Tohu ve Bohu" (Now the earth was unformed and void).

critical_analysis.relevance: Talmud Eser Sefirot (TES) is the most comprehensive systematic exposition of Lurianic Kabbalah, authored by Rabbi Yehuda Leib Ashlag (Baal HaSulam). Part 6, specifically 'The Eser Sefirot of Olam ha Nekudim,' is of paramount importance as it details the critical stage of emanation following Adam Kadmon, leading to the Shevirat ha Kelim (Breaking of Vessels). This event is the central tenet of Lurianic cosmogony, explaining the presence of imperfection, exile, and the need for Tikun (Rectification). For a practitioner of Western Esotericism and Qabalah, a deep understanding of this text is indispensable, as it provides the foundational metaphysics for virtually all subsequent Kabbalistic practices aimed at spiritual and cosmic repair. The intricate descriptions of Partzufim, Tzimtzum, Masach, Parsa, and the dynamics of Ohr and Kelim offer an unparalleled technical insight into how spiritual realms are structured and interact. The emphasis on the ascent of MAN (Mayin Nukvin) subtly points to the operative role of human consciousness and intention in influencing these higher processes, making it a 'technical manual' for advanced spiritual work rather than a ceremonial one.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience for this work is advanced students and practitioners of Lurianic Kabbalah, particularly those deeply engaged in the rigorous academic and practical study of Rabbi Yehuda Leib Ashlag's system. It assumes prior comprehensive knowledge of foundational Kabbalistic concepts, terminology, and the framework established in earlier parts of TES. The text's density, complex conceptual layering, and frequent references to numerical values (Gimatria) and esoteric correspondences make it unsuitable for beginners. It functions as a highly specialized academic and operative manual for those seeking to understand the precise mechanics of divine emanation, the root of cosmic imperfection, and the sophisticated methodology for its rectification.
